question.title: What does it mean when Eclipse displays a "Login required" dialog window on launch?
question.body:
May be related to my other question.
Eclipse IDE for Java Developers 2025-09 on Windows 10.
When launching the IDE, i.e. running file eclipse.exe (in the Eclipse installation folder), one of the messages in the status bar is Deferred Early Start â€“ as shown in below image.

After that message is displayed, the following dialog Window appears.
(Note that I have erased the actual name of the server in the URL. It is on the network of my place of work.)

I don't enter any details and click on the OK button.
Eclipse finishes launching and I don't have any [apparent] problems using the IDE.
I want to know what Eclipse is trying to log in to and whether not supplying login details has any consequences.
Note that I have been using Eclipse IDE for many years, always the most up-to-date version and the behavior described above only started occurring since version 2025-06 (4.36.0). Also, WindowBuilder is also installed.

EDIT

Replying to comment (from the busybee):
I added a local update site to the list of update sites in order to perform an offline installation of WindowBuilder.

EDIT 2

Replying to comment (from howlger):
List of update sites.

Startup and Shutdown

question_comments.body: @Abra I specifically wanted to know whether that is a proxy server used in your network - so that your HTTP(s) traffic would be using that proxy which may need authentication. Do you know what that server (+ port) is used for? Eclipse doesn't contact random servers. If that server wants authentication, there's probably a reason Eclipse tries to use it (e.g. it being a proxy server or something telling Eclipse to get updates there).
@dan1st yes, the server is in our work network and I did mention that in the body of the question. Or do I misunderstand what you are asking?
Is the URL from the modal possibly a proxy server in your network?

@Abra I'm pretty sure this is the fallout of you removing those asc files from the zip. Eclipse is trying to connect to its own internal 'update site' and the UI mostly assumes that can't fail. It normally wouldn't, but without the ASC files...)
@howlger question is edited and contains information that you requested.
The update sites are listed in Window > Preferences > Install/Update > Available Software Sites. Please also show what you have in Window > Preferences > General > Startup and Shutdown.

check the proxy settings (since port 8080) - also possible that Eclipse is trying to connect to itself (P2/OSGI framework) but the PGP key, signature, or similar was deleted (based on linked question)  - deleting that information is not really a security improvement (IMO)
The URL looks like a local test port for HTTP. Did you add a local update site to the list of update sites?
